description: Enables you to programmatically create an Amazon Web Services Supply Chain data lake dataset. Developers can create the datasets using their pre-defined or custom schema for a given instance ID, namespace, and dataset name.

parameters.name: instanceId
parameters.description: The Amazon Web Services Supply Chain instance identifier.

parameters.name: namespace
parameters.description: The namespace of the dataset, besides the custom defined namespace, every instance comes with below pre-defined namespaces: asc - For information on the Amazon Web Services Supply Chain supported datasets see https://docs.aws.amazon.com/aws-supply-chain/latest/userguide/data-model-asc.html. default - For datasets with custom user-defined schemas.

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name of the dataset. For asc name space, the name must be one of the supported data entities under https://docs.aws.amazon.com/aws-supply-chain/latest/userguide/data-model-asc.html.

parameters.name: schema
parameters.description: The custom schema of the data lake dataset and required for dataset in default and custom namespaces. The name of the dataset schema. The list of field details of the dataset schema. (dict) --- The dataset field details. The dataset field name. The dataset field type. Indicate if the field is required or not. primaryKeys (list) --- The list of primary key fields for the dataset. Primary keys defined can help data ingestion methods to ensure data uniqueness: CreateDataIntegrationFlow's dedupe strategy will leverage primary keys to perform records deduplication before write to dataset; SendDataIntegrationEvent's UPSERT and DELETE can only work with dataset with primary keys. For more details, refer to those data ingestion documentations. Note that defining primary keys does not necessarily mean the dataset cannot have duplicate records, duplicate records can still be ingested if CreateDataIntegrationFlow's dedupe disabled or through SendDataIntegrationEvent's APPEND operation. (dict) --- The detail of the primary key field. The name of the primary key field.

nested_params.name: name
nested_params.description: The name of the dataset schema.

nested_params.name: fields
nested_params.description: The list of field details of the dataset schema.

nested_params.name: isRequired
nested_params.description: Indicate if the field is required or not.

nested_params.name: primaryKeys
nested_params.description: The list of primary key fields for the dataset. Primary keys defined can help data ingestion methods to ensure data uniqueness: CreateDataIntegrationFlow's dedupe strategy will leverage primary keys to perform records deduplication before write to dataset; SendDataIntegrationEvent's UPSERT and DELETE can only work with dataset with primary keys. For more details, refer to those data ingestion documentations. Note that defining primary keys does not necessarily mean the dataset cannot have duplicate records, duplicate records can still be ingested if CreateDataIntegrationFlow's dedupe disabled or through SendDataIntegrationEvent's APPEND operation.

nested_params.name: name
nested_params.description: The name of the primary key field.

parameters.name: partitionSpec
parameters.description: The partition specification of the dataset. Partitioning can effectively improve the dataset query performance by reducing the amount of data scanned during query execution. But partitioning or not will affect how data get ingested by data ingestion methods, such as SendDataIntegrationEvent's dataset UPSERT will upsert records within partition (instead of within whole dataset). For more details, refer to those data ingestion documentations. The fields on which to partition a dataset. The partitions will be applied hierarchically based on the order of this list. (dict) --- The detail of the partition field. The name of the partition field. The transformation of the partition field. A transformation specifies how to partition on a given field. For example, with timestamp you can specify that you'd like to partition fields by day, e.g. data record with value 2025-01-03T00:00:00Z in partition field is in 2025-01-03 partition. Also noted that data record without any value in optional partition field is in NULL partition. The type of partitioning transformation for this field. The available options are: IDENTITY - Partitions data on a given field by its exact values. YEAR - Partitions data on a timestamp field using year granularity. MONTH - Partitions data on a timestamp field using month granularity. DAY - Partitions data on a timestamp field using day granularity. HOUR - Partitions data on a timestamp field using hour granularity.

nested_params.name: fields
nested_params.description: The fields on which to partition a dataset. The partitions will be applied hierarchically based on the order of this list.

nested_params.name: name
nested_params.description: The name of the partition field.

nested_params.name: transform
nested_params.description: The transformation of the partition field. A transformation specifies how to partition on a given field. For example, with timestamp you can specify that you'd like to partition fields by day, e.g. data record with value 2025-01-03T00:00:00Z in partition field is in 2025-01-03 partition. Also noted that data record without any value in optional partition field is in NULL partition.

nested_params.name: type
nested_params.description: The type of partitioning transformation for this field. The available options are:
